summary: This is the U.S. Government's omnibus memorandum in opposition to Ghislaine Maxwell's thirteen motions in limine in her criminal case (S2 20 Cr. 330). It argues for the admissibility of expert testimony on trauma psychology, evidence related to Minor Victim-3, co-conspirator statements, identification evidence, and various exhibits, while also addressing defense motions to preclude terms like 'victim' and evidence of rape. The document outlines the prosecution's trial strategy and legal arguments.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant charged with conspiracy and other crimes related to the sexual exploitation of minors with Jeffrey Epstein. The Government opposes her motions to exclude evidence.

persons.name: Damian Williams
persons.role: United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York
persons.context: The prosecutor who submitted this memorandum on behalf of the U.S. Government.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Deceased financier and alleged co-conspirator with Maxwell in the sexual abuse and trafficking of minor girls. His actions and relationship with Maxwell are central to the case.

persons.name: Minor Victim-1
persons.context: A minor victim allegedly abused by Epstein and Maxwell between approximately 1994 and 1997.

persons.name: Minor Victim-2
persons.context: A minor victim allegedly abused by Epstein and Maxwell in 1996.

persons.name: Minor Victim-3
persons.context: A minor victim allegedly groomed and befriended by Maxwell in London between 1994 and 1995 and introduced to Epstein for sexual abuse. Her testimony is a subject of a defense motion.

persons.name: Minor Victim-4
persons.context: A minor victim allegedly trafficked by Maxwell and Epstein from approximately 2001 to 2004. Her identification of Maxwell is challenged by the defense.

persons.name: Employee-1
persons.context: A witness who worked for Epstein after the charged conduct and is expected to testify about the operations at Epstein's properties, the relationship between Maxwell and Epstein, and observations of minor girls.

persons.name: Employee-2
persons.context: An employee who worked for Epstein during the timeframe of the charged conspiracy and is referenced in the indictment. Employee-1 reported to this person.

persons.name: Dr. Rocchio
persons.context: A clinical psychologist and trauma expert the Government intends to call to testify about general principles of coercion, attachment, grooming, and delayed disclosure in child sexual abuse cases. She has not evaluated any victims in this case.

connections.description: Alleged co-conspirators in a scheme to sexually exploit and traffic minor girls. The document describes their close relationship and Maxwell's role in procuring victims for Epstein.
Maxwell allegedly groomed and befriended Minor Victim-3 in London and introduced her to Epstein for sexual abuse.
Maxwell allegedly trafficked Minor Victim-4 and paid her after sexual encounters with Epstein.
Epstein allegedly sexually abused Minor Victim-3 after Maxwell introduced them.
Employee-1 worked as a personal assistant for Epstein and reported to Employee-2.
Employee-1 worked out of Maxwell's townhouse in Manhattan and observed the close relationship between Maxwell and Epstein.
Employee-1 reported directly to Employee-2 while working for Epstein.

events.title: Grooming and Abuse of Minor Victim-3
events.description: Maxwell allegedly groomed and befriended Minor Victim-3 in London, introduced her to Epstein, and encouraged her to massage Epstein, leading to sexual abuse.

events.title: Trafficking of Minor Victim-4
events.description: Maxwell and Epstein allegedly trafficked Minor Victim-4 for sexual abuse. Maxwell paid Minor Victim-4 after encounters with Epstein.

events.title: Search of Epstein's Palm Beach Home
events.description: Law enforcement executed a search warrant at Jeffrey Epstein's home in Palm Beach, Florida, seizing evidence including contact books, computers, and sex toys.

events.title: FBI Interview of Minor Victim-4
events.description: Minor Victim-4 was interviewed by the FBI and described meeting an older woman with short black hair and an unknown accent (consistent with Maxwell) at her first meeting with Epstein.

events.title: Photo Identification by Minor Victim-4
events.description: The Government showed Minor Victim-4 a photo book containing 20 photos. She identified a photo of Ghislaine Maxwell, confirming her previous knowledge of the defendant.

events.title: Government's Pre-trial Disclosures
events.description: The Government provided the defense with Jencks Act materials, Rule 404(b) notice, co-conspirator statements, exhibit list, and witness list, as ordered by the court.

keyFacts: The Government plans to call Dr. Rocchio as an expert witness to testify about general psychological principles in child sexual abuse cases, including grooming, coercion, attachment, and delayed disclosure.
Evidence related to Minor Victim-3 is argued to be direct evidence of the charged conspiracies, showing a pattern of conduct by Maxwell and Epstein, and is also admissible under Rule 404(b).

The Government asserts it has complied with pre-trial disclosure obligations regarding co-conspirator statements by providing Jencks Act materials and exhibits, and opposes the defense's request for a separate itemized list.
Minor Victim-4's identification of Maxwell from a photo array is defended as a non-suggestive 'confirmatory identification' due to Minor Victim-4's prior personal interactions with Maxwell.
The Government argues it is proper to use the term 'victim' and to present evidence of rape, as these are relevant to the charged crimes of sexual exploitation and trafficking of minors.
